elements.title: Gift-Signal Visual Weight: Gifts Visually Dominate Requests
elements.problem: When the platform shows both gift information (what the host receives) and request information (what the host must provide) on the same screen, the visual weight is currently equal or tilted toward requests. Form fields, input borders, placeholder text, and submit buttons all carry strong visual weight through their functional styling. Gift information (earnings estimates, included services, pre-filled data) is typically rendered as secondary text -- smaller, lighter, less prominent. This visual imbalance contradicts Cialdini's reciprocity principle: if the gift is not visually dominant, it does not feel like a gift. It feels like fine print. Bryant makes his gifts dominant on the call through vocal emphasis, timing (gifts come first), and volume (he spends more time on what he offers than on what he needs). The platform must achieve the same dominance visually.
elements.solution: Establish a visual weight system where gift information is always visually heavier than request information on any shared screen. (1) Gift headlines: use Inter at --text-xl (20px), --font-weight-bold (700), color --primary-purple (#31135D). This is the largest, heaviest text on any page that mixes gifts and requests. (2) Gift supporting text: use DM Sans at --text-md (16px), --font-weight-medium (500), color --text-dark (#1a1a1a). Generous line-height (--line-height-relaxed, 1.6) for readability. (3) Gift containers: bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) with --shadow-purple-sm (0 2px 4px rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.2)) and --rounded-xl (12px). The purple-tinted shadow signals 'this is from the platform, for you.' (4) Request elements (form fields, buttons): visually lighter -- Inter at --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), standard --border-color (#e5e7eb) borders, no shadow. (5) The visual hierarchy ratio: gift elements should occupy 60%+ of above-the-fold space. Request elements should be positioned below or alongside gifts, never above them.

evidence.quote: Bryant spends approximately 18 of 27 minutes giving information (gifts) and 9 minutes receiving information (Sherene's concerns and responses). This 2:1 ratio of giving to receiving is what creates the reciprocal obligation. The visual equivalent must maintain a similar ratio.
evidence.insight: The 2:1 gift-to-request ratio in the call is what drives engagement. The platform must replicate this visually: gift content should be roughly twice as visually prominent as request content on any mixed-purpose screen.

evidence.quote: The unsuspecting passerby who suddenly finds a flower pressed into his hands... Only after the Krishna member has thus brought the force of the reciprocation rule to bear on the situation is the target asked to provide a contribution.
evidence.insight: The flower is the first and most visible thing -- it dominates the encounter visually and physically before any request is made. The platform equivalent: the gift (earnings estimate, guest profile, pre-filled data) must visually dominate the screen before any form field or button appears. The gift must be as impossible to miss as a flower pressed into your hands.

colors: --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for gift accent elements and icons
typography: Gift body: DM Sans, 500 weight, 16px (--text-md), line-height 1.6
spacing: --spacing-xl (20px) between gift container and first request element
new_tokens_needed: --gift-container-bg: a distinct background for gift sections, possibly rgb(252, 250, 255) with a subtle left border in --secondary-purple. Not currently a named token in the system.
--gift-shadow: a gift-specific shadow that combines purple tint with slight elevation, distinguishing gift containers from standard cards. Proposal: 0 2px 8px rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.12).

elements.contrast_requirements: Gift headline (#31135D on rgb(252, 250, 255)): contrast ratio approximately 12:1, exceeds WCAG AAA. Gift body text (#1a1a1a on rgb(252, 250, 255)): contrast ratio approximately 16:1, exceeds WCAG AAA. Request label (#1a1a1a on #ffffff): contrast ratio 16:1, WCAG AAA. All combinations comfortably exceed WCAG AA minimum of 4.5:1.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: On any screen containing both gift and request elements: (1) The eye hits the gift headline first (largest, boldest, highest on page). (2) The eye moves to the gift container (distinct background, purple shadow, generous padding). (3) The eye descends to request elements (lighter, smaller, standard styling). This hierarchy must hold on both mobile (single column, gift above request) and desktop (gift can be left column, request right column, with gift column visually wider).
elements.brand_alignment: The gift-dominant visual pattern reinforces Split Lease's brand as a platform that gives before it asks -- sophisticated (purple palette), generous (gift-first layout), and trustworthy (information-rich gift containers). Aligns with the Style-guide.md philosophy of 'clean, modern interfaces with a distinctive purple palette that conveys trust and sophistication.'

elements.title: Stranger-to-Person Visual Progression in Guest Profiles
elements.problem: Guest profiles currently present all information in a flat, uniform visual style -- text fields in a card, possibly with an avatar. This visual flatness does not mirror the emotional arc of meeting a person. When Bryant reveals Greg and Johan to Sherene, there is a progression: abstract concept ('two guests') -> named individuals ('Greg' and 'Johan') -> humanized details (ages, jobs, hometowns) -> relatable context ('both from Connecticut, hybrid workers'). Each revelation reduces the 'stranger' anxiety. Visually, the platform must create this same arc: from anonymous to personal to trusted. The current flat profile card fails to create this progression because everything looks the same -- the guest's name has the same visual weight as their employment status.
elements.solution: Design guest profiles with a three-tier visual progression that mirrors the stranger-to-person emotional arc. (1) Tier 1 -- The Person (always visible, maximum visual weight): Large avatar circle (--avatar-lg, 80px) with warm shadow (--shadow-purple-sm). Guest name in Inter, --text-xl (20px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple. Age and one-sentence summary below in DM Sans, --text-md (16px), --text-dark. This tier occupies 40% of the profile card's visual space. (2) Tier 2 -- The Context (visible on engagement, medium visual weight): Schedule badges using the existing day-badge component (--chat-purple background for active days). Employment and origin in Inter, --text-base (14px), --text-gray (#6b7280). Separated from Tier 1 by a subtle divider (--border-color). This tier occupies 35% of space. (3) Tier 3 -- The Verification (expandable, lowest visual weight): Vetting results, custom question answers, and references. Displayed in a collapsible section with --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6) background, --text-sm (12px) for data labels, --text-base (14px) for values. This tier is visually quieter to signal that it is supporting evidence, not the primary story. The progression from Tier 1 to Tier 3 should feel like zooming in: from the person to the details to the proof.

evidence.quote: Tier 1 equivalent: 'Greg' and 'Johan' -- names emerge at 00:50. Tier 2 equivalent: 'Greg is interior design... 28... from Connecticut' (09:06-12:00). Tier 3 equivalent: 'I can share our vetting form with them' (16:39). Bryant naturally structures disclosure in three tiers with decreasing novelty and increasing verification.
evidence.insight: The visual design must mirror this natural disclosure sequence. Tier 1 (name, face, summary) creates the person. Tier 2 (job, schedule, origin) creates the context. Tier 3 (vetting, references) creates the trust. Each tier reduces stranger-anxiety progressively.

evidence.quote: The interesting thing about the Regan experiment is that the relationship between liking and compliance was completely wiped out in the condition under which subjects had been given a Coke by Joe. For those who owed him a favor, it made no difference whether they liked him or not.
evidence.insight: The visual profile must create enough gift-obligation (platform gives you a detailed, humanized profile of your future guest) that the host feels compelled to engage even if the guest's details are not perfectly aligned with their preferences. The profile IS the gift -- its visual richness is what creates the reciprocal obligation to consider the guest seriously.

typography: Tier 1 summary: DM Sans, 400 weight, 16px (--text-md), line-height 1.6
Tier 2 schedule: Inter, 600 weight, 13px (--text-sm-md) inside day badges
spacing: --spacing-2xl (24px) padding inside the full profile card
--spacing-lg (16px) between Tier 2 and Tier 3 expandable section
new_tokens_needed: --avatar-warm-shadow: a shadow for guest avatars that feels human/warm rather than functional. Proposal: 0 4px 12px rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.15). Distinct from --shadow-purple-sm by being slightly larger and softer.
--tier-transition-bg: a subtle gradient or background shift between disclosure tiers. Proposal: fade from rgb(252, 250, 255) to #ffffff over 8px. Not currently in the token system.

elements.contrast_requirements: Tier 1 name (#31135D on rgb(252, 250, 255)): ~12:1, WCAG AAA. Tier 1 summary (#1a1a1a on rgb(252, 250, 255)): ~16:1, AAA. Tier 2 details (#6b7280 on #ffffff): ~4.6:1, WCAG AA (meets minimum; consider proposed --text-gray #5A6370 at 5.9:1 for improvement). Day badge text (#ffffff on rgb(75, 71, 206)): ~4.7:1, WCAG AA. Tier 3 labels (#6b7280 on #f3f4f6): ~3.8:1, below AA for small text. Recommendation: use --text-description (#374151) for Tier 3 labels to achieve 7.1:1.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The guest's face (avatar) and name must be the first and most visually dominant elements. The schedule badges must be the second-most prominent (they answer the host's immediate question: 'When will this person be in my home?'). Verification data must be visually quietest -- it is proof, not personality. On mobile, the three tiers stack vertically with clear visual breaks. On desktop, Tier 1 can be left-aligned with a large avatar, Tiers 2-3 right-aligned.
elements.brand_alignment: The three-tier guest profile aligns with Split Lease's brand positioning as human-first, not transaction-first. By leading with the person (name, face, story) rather than the transaction (dates, prices, terms), the profile reinforces the brand's warmth within its purple sophistication. The progressive disclosure mirrors the conversational quality that Sherene explicitly valued: 'Some things are just better understood with the conversation.'

elements.title: Reciprocity Health Indicator: Visual Status for Active Lease Balance
elements.problem: During the active lease, the host needs at-a-glance visual confirmation that the reciprocal arrangement is balanced -- that guests are fulfilling obligations and payments are flowing. Currently, there is no unified visual indicator for this. The host must check multiple sections (payments, messages, cleaning records) to assess the health of the arrangement. For the ghost roommate model, this problem is amplified: two guests mean twice as many reciprocity touchpoints to track. Cialdini's research shows that visible reciprocity creates pressure to maintain balance. Without a clear visual status, the host operates in anxiety mode -- assuming the worst because they cannot see evidence of the best.
elements.solution: Design a Reciprocity Health Indicator -- a persistent visual element on the active lease dashboard that shows the overall balance status at a glance. (1) Visual form: a compact status bar or card at the top of the lease view with three sub-indicators: Payment Status, Cleaning Status, and Schedule Status. Each sub-indicator uses a traffic-light system (green dot, amber dot, red dot) with a one-line text label. (2) Green state: filled circle in --success-green (#4B47CE -- the production purple that serves as success) with label 'All payments on time' / 'Cleaning checklists complete' / 'Schedule on track.' (3) Amber state: filled circle in --status-warning (#C4841D from proposed tokens) with label describing the pending issue. (4) Red state: filled circle in --status-error (#C53030 from proposed tokens) with label and action link. (5) The overall indicator background should be --bg-light (#f9fafb) with a subtle left border in the dominant status color (green if all good, amber if any amber, red if any red). (6) On the retention screen (end of lease), transform the health indicator into a cumulative summary: 'Over 3 months: 100% on-time payments, 96% cleaning completion, 0 schedule conflicts.' Use --primary-purple for the cumulative text to signal premium/accomplishment.

evidence.quote: Sherene: 'I just don't always think about the worst case.' Bryant: 'We want to help you be protected from that.'
evidence.insight: Sherene acknowledges she is not a worst-case thinker. The visual health indicator replaces the need for worst-case thinking: if the indicator is green, Sherene knows everything is fine without having to investigate. The indicator IS the protection Bryant promised -- made visible.

evidence.quote: Cultural anthropologists view this web of indebtedness as a unique adaptive mechanism of human beings, allowing for the division of labor, the exchange of diverse forms of goods, and the creation of interdependencies that bind individuals together.
evidence.insight: The ghost roommate arrangement is a web of indebtedness. The visual health indicator makes this web visible: the host can see that each thread (payment, cleaning, schedule) is intact. When all threads are green, the web is strong. When one is amber, attention is needed. When one is red, the web is at risk. Visibility is what holds the web together.

colors: --success-green (#4B47CE) for healthy status indicators (production success color)
--status-warning (#C4841D from proposed palette) for pending/attention items
--status-error (#C53030 from proposed palette) for broken reciprocity items
--primary-purple (#31135D) for cumulative summary text at retention
spacing: --spacing-2xl (24px) margin below the status bar before main content
new_tokens_needed: --status-dot-size: 10px filled circle for status dots. Not currently in the token system. Should be added as a component token.
--status-border-left-width: 4px for the left accent border on the status bar container. Thicker than --border-width-thick (2px) to create a distinct status signal.

elements.contrast_requirements: Green status (#4B47CE) on --bg-light (#f9fafb): ~4.8:1, meets WCAG AA. Warning status (#C4841D) on --bg-light: ~4.6:1, meets WCAG AA. Error status (#C53030) on --bg-light: ~6.1:1, meets WCAG AA. All status labels use --text-dark on --bg-light: 16:1, WCAG AAA. Status detail text uses --text-gray on --bg-light: ~4.6:1, meets WCAG AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The status indicator must be the first thing the host sees on the active lease dashboard -- positioned at the absolute top of the content area, below the navigation but above any other content. The overall status (green/amber/red left border) should be perceivable in under 1 second. Individual sub-indicators should be scannable left-to-right in under 3 seconds. The indicator should be visually distinct from content below it (using the accent left border and the --bg-light background) so the eye naturally pauses on it before scrolling.
elements.brand_alignment: The status indicator uses the production purple (#4B47CE) for success states, maintaining brand consistency even in functional UI. The proposed warm status colors (amber #C4841D, red #C53030) from Paula Scher's audit add the warmth needed for attention and urgency states without introducing off-brand greens or yellows. The cumulative summary at retention uses --primary-purple at large scale, reinforcing the brand's premium positioning for hosts reviewing their earning history.

elements.title: Concession-Contrast Visual Treatment for Pricing Comparisons
elements.problem: Cialdini's contrast principle shows that presenting a lower anchor before a higher value makes the higher value appear more attractive. Bryant uses this verbally: he mentions $1000 first, then says the ghost roommate arrangement will pay MORE than $1000. The contrast makes $1200 feel generous rather than merely adequate. The platform's pricing UI currently shows a single number without contrast anchoring. There is no visual mechanism to show what the host WOULD earn (lower) versus what they WILL earn (higher). Without this contrast, the ghost roommate premium is invisible -- $1200 is just a number, not a premium. The visual treatment must create the contrast that makes the premium feel like a concession from the platform (Cialdini's rejection-then-retreat: the platform 'retreats' from the lower number to the higher one).
elements.solution: Design pricing comparisons with a deliberate contrast visual treatment that anchors the lower value before revealing the higher value. (1) Lower anchor: show the standard/baseline earning in a muted visual treatment -- Inter, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-gray (#6b7280), no emphasis, possibly with a light strikethrough or 'Starting from' label. Background: none or --bg-light-gray. (2) Higher value (the concession/premium): show in a prominent visual treatment -- DM Sans, --text-2xl (28px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple (#31135D), with a purple-tinted background container (--bg-off-white) and a subtle upward-pointing arrow or '+' prefix in --secondary-purple. (3) The visual transition from lower to higher should use vertical layout (lower above, higher below, larger) or left-to-right (lower left, arrow, higher right). The higher value must be visually at least 2x the size of the lower anchor. (4) Include a 'premium' badge near the higher value: a small pill-shaped element (--rounded-pill, 20px) with --secondary-purple background and white text reading 'Ghost Roommate Premium' or 'Your Arrangement.' This badge explains WHY the number is higher. (5) For the daily payment detail: show '$40/night' in --text-md, below the monthly total, with a calendar icon in --secondary-purple to signal the daily payment rhythm.

evidence.source: cialdini-intro-reciprocity.txt, Ch 1 - Contrast Principle in retail
evidence.quote: Sell the suit first, because when it comes time to look at sweaters, even expensive ones, their prices will not seem as high in comparison. The same principle applies to a man who wishes to buy the accessories to go along with his new suit.
evidence.insight: Show the lower anchor (standard earning) first, then the higher value (ghost roommate earning). The contrast makes the premium feel larger. But unlike the clothing store example, here the platform WANTS the host to feel the premium is generous, not that the base is inadequate. The visual treatment must celebrate the higher number while using the lower number only as a quiet anchor.

evidence.quote: Bryant: 'Typically... we're able to provide the host with a better price than what they're asking for. And it looks like this will be the case as well, where we can give you more than a thousand.' Sherene: 'And you said a thousand combined?' Bryant: 'It'll likely be more than that... I think it'll probably be closer to 11 or 1200.'
evidence.insight: Bryant verbally anchors at $1000 (the lower value Sherene mentioned), then reveals the higher value ($1100-$1200). The vocal emphasis is on 'more than' and 'better than.' The visual treatment must replicate this emphasis: the word 'more' or the '+' symbol should carry visual weight, connecting the lower anchor to the higher premium.

--primary-purple (#31135D) for the higher premium value (dominant, celebrated)
--secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for the premium badge and '+' prefix

Premium badge: Inter, 600 weight, 11px (--text-xs), white on --secondary-purple

--spacing-lg (16px) between premium container and daily detail

--price-anchor-opacity: opacity for the lower anchor value to visually subordinate it without hiding it. Proposal: 0.7. Not currently in the opacity token set which only has disabled (0.5), hover (0.8), and focus (0.9).

elements.contrast_requirements: Higher premium (#31135D on rgb(252, 250, 255)): ~12:1, WCAG AAA. Lower anchor (#6b7280 on #f3f4f6): ~3.8:1, below AA for body text but acceptable for secondary/anchor text that is not essential reading (the host is not meant to focus on the lower number). Premium badge (white on rgb(109, 49, 194)): ~5.8:1, WCAG AA. Daily detail (#1a1a1a on white): 16:1, AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The premium value must be the largest and most prominent element on any pricing screen. It should be at least 2x the font size of the anchor value. The eye path should be: (1) Premium number in --primary-purple, (2) Premium badge explaining the premium, (3) Anchor value providing contrast context, (4) Daily breakdown providing operational detail. On mobile, this is a vertical stack. On desktop, the premium can be centered with the anchor value as a smaller, left-aligned label above it.
elements.brand_alignment: The pricing contrast treatment uses the brand's strongest color (--primary-purple #31135D) for the most important number on the page. This aligns with the brand principle that purple conveys premium value. The premium badge in --secondary-purple creates a cohesive purple hierarchy: deep purple for the price, vibrant purple for the explanation. The overall effect is aspirational and generous, matching Split Lease's positioning as a platform that helps hosts earn more, not just find tenants.

elements.title: Daily Payment Pulse: Visual Rhythm for Reciprocity Reinforcement
elements.problem: Daily payment notifications risk becoming invisible through repetition. Cialdini's reciprocity research shows that the power of a gift diminishes if it becomes routine and unnoticed. The visual challenge: make each daily payment notification feel like a distinct gift, not a routine system message, while maintaining visual consistency with the brand. The current notification style (if implemented) likely uses a standard alert pattern -- same color, same layout, same wording -- which habituates the host and reduces the reciprocal reinforcement effect. Each payment must feel fresh and personally relevant, like Bryant saying 'I'll compensate you for Greg's stay' (not 'Payment #17 of 90').
elements.solution: Design daily payment notifications with a visual rhythm pattern that creates variation within consistency. (1) Base container: a compact card (max-width 320px on mobile, 400px on desktop) with --bg-white background, --rounded-lg (8px) corners, --shadow-sm for subtle elevation. Left accent border in --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)), 3px wide. (2) Primary content: payment amount in DM Sans, --text-lg (18px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple. Guest name in Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-medium (500), --text-dark. Night description in Inter, --text-sm (12px), --text-gray. (3) Running total: a subtle progress bar below the payment details showing monthly accumulation. Use --gradient-purple-button for the filled portion, --bg-light-gray for the unfilled portion. Label: 'This month: $X of $1,200 target' in --text-sm, --text-gray. (4) Visual variation: alternate the accent icon between a small calendar icon (Feather icon 'calendar') for weekday stays and a small home icon (Feather icon 'home') for weekend stays. This subtle variation prevents visual habituation while maintaining the purple brand. (5) Micro-animation: on arrival, the payment amount should count up from $0 to the full amount over 0.3s (--transition-slow) with --easing-ease-out. This creates a moment of visual delight that reinforces the 'gift received' feeling.

evidence.quote: Bryant: 'After the first night of each stay, we'll compensate you for that person's stay. So for example, after Monday night, you would get compensation for Greg's stay, if that makes sense.'
evidence.insight: Bryant ties each payment to a specific guest and a specific night. The notification must do the same: 'Greg stayed Monday night. $40 paid.' This specificity prevents the notification from feeling generic and maintains the personal reciprocity connection.

evidence.quote: The rule says that we should try to repay, in kind, what another person has provided us. If a woman does us a favor, we should do her one in return.
evidence.insight: The payment notification is the platform's reciprocal gift for the host's gift of shelter. The visual treatment must make this reciprocity explicit: 'You hosted Greg. We paid you $40.' The visual pairing (hosting action -> payment response) reinforces the reciprocal cycle with each notification.

--spacing-xs (4px) between guest name and night description

--progress-bar-height: 4px for the monthly accumulation progress bar. Not currently in the sizing token system.

elements.contrast_requirements: Payment amount (#31135D on #ffffff): 16:1, WCAG AAA. Guest name (#1a1a1a on #ffffff): 16:1, AAA. Night description (#6b7280 on #ffffff): 4.6:1, WCAG AA. Left accent border (rgb(109, 49, 194) on #ffffff): decorative, no text contrast required. Progress bar text (#6b7280 on #ffffff): 4.6:1, AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The payment amount must be the first element the eye hits -- largest text, darkest purple, at the top of the notification. The guest name provides immediate context (who). The night description provides temporal context (when). The progress bar provides cumulative context (how much total). This hierarchy mirrors the conversational reveal: amount first (the gift), then context (who gave what for whom).
elements.brand_alignment: The daily payment notification is the most frequent brand touchpoint during the active lease -- the host sees it every day. The purple accent border and --primary-purple payment amount ensure every notification reinforces the Split Lease brand. The subtle count-up animation and progress bar add a moment of delight that distinguishes Split Lease from a generic payment processor. The variation (calendar vs home icon) adds personality without breaking brand consistency.
